intro: Chlorocodon scoparium, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a member of the Asparagaceae family. It is a flowering plant native to New Zealand, characterized by its sword-shaped leaves and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. The plant is known for its fibrous bark, which has been historically used by Māori for weaving and other crafts. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in forest margins and wetlands. Chlorocodon scoparium plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
